title: St. Albans (city), Vermont
text:
St. Albans is the <a href="county%20seat">county seat</a> of <a href="Franklin%20County%2C%20Vermont">Franklin County, Vermont</a>, United States. At the <a href="United%20States%20Census%2C%202020">2020 census</a>, the city population was 6,877. St. Albans City is surrounded by <a href="St.%20Albans%20%28town%29%2C%20Vermont">the town of Saint Albans</a> which is incorporated separately from the city of St. Albans. The city is located in Northwestern Vermont in Franklin County. It lies 29 miles north of <a href="Burlington%2C%20Vermont">Burlington</a>, the state's most populous city which is located in <a href="Chittenden%20County%2C%20Vermont">Chittenden County</a>.
History.
One of the <a href="New%20Hampshire%20grants">New Hampshire grants</a>, St. Albans was chartered by Colonial Governor <a href="Benning%20Wentworth">Benning Wentworth</a> on August 17, 1763, to Stephen Pomeroy and 63 others. Named after <a href="St%20Albans">St Albans</a>, <a href="Hertfordshire">Hertfordshire</a>, <a href="England">England</a>, it was first settled during the <a href="American%20Revolution">Revolution</a> by Jesse Welden. The war delayed further settlement until 1785, when many others began to arrive. Farmers found the rich, dark <a href="loam">loam</a> suitable for <a href="Tillage">cultivation</a>, as well as for the raising of <a href="cattle">cattle</a>, <a href="horse">horse</a>s and <a href="sheep">sheep</a>. <a href="Butter">Butter</a> and <a href="cheese">cheese</a> were produced in great quantities. St. Albans also became known as "Railroad City," home to a major <a href="train%20station">depot</a>, operations center and repair shop of the <a href="Vermont%20and%20Canada%20Railroad">Vermont and Canada Railroad</a>. When the village was incorporated in 1859, it had an <a href="iron">iron</a> <a href="foundry">foundry</a>, a manufacturer of <a href="freight%20car">freight car</a>s, and a large number of <a href="mechanic">mechanic</a> shops.
The northernmost engagement of the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">Civil War</a>, known as the <a href="St.%20Albans%20Raid">St. Albans Raid</a>, occurred here on October 19, 1864. In 1902, the City of St. Albans was incorporated, comprising two square miles (518 hectares) within the town of <a href="St.%20Albans%20%28town%29%2C%20Vermont">St. Albans</a>. Today it is a <a href="tourist%20destination">tourist destination</a> noted for its <a href="Victorian%20architecture">Victorian</a> and <a href="American%20Craftsman">Craftsman</a> style <a href="architecture">architecture</a> built during the railroad era, when over 200 trains a day passed through. St. Albans is a research target for <a href="genealogy">genealogists</a>, as <a href="Europe">Europe</a>an <a href="immigrant">immigrant</a>s heading for the United States would sometimes land in Canada at <a href="City%20of%20Halifax">Halifax</a>, <a href="Nova%20Scotia">Nova Scotia</a> or <a href="Montreal%2C%20Quebec">Montreal, Quebec</a>, then take a train through the border crossing here. The <a href="United%20States%20National%20Archives">National Archives</a> (NARA) lists for St. Albans cover the period 1895–1954.
Culture.
In late April St. Albans hosts the annual Vermont <a href="Sugar%20Maple">Maple</a> Festival. The festival includes various food-related contests, as well as the Sap Run, a footrace from <a href="Swanton%20%28town%29%2C%20Vermont">Swanton</a>, to the north. It was home to the <a href="Vermont%20Voltage">Vermont Voltage</a>, a semi-professional men's soccer team, which folded in 2014.
Geography.
According to the <a href="United%20States%20Census%20Bureau">United States Census Bureau</a>, the city has a total area of 2.0 square miles (5.3 km2), all land. The city is surrounded by the town of <a href="St.%20Albans%20%28town%29%2C%20Vermont">St. Albans</a>, with its lush <a href="arable%20land">farmland</a> across gently rolling hills. The city is drained by Stevens Brook.
St. Albans is crossed by <a href="Interstate%2089">Interstate 89</a>, <a href="U.S.%20Route%207%20in%20Vermont">U.S. Route 7</a>, as well as <a href="Vermont%20Route%2036">Vermont Route 36</a>, 38, 104 and <a href="Vermont%20Route%20105">105</a>. It is about from Vermont's border with <a href="Quebec">Quebec</a>.
Demographics.
At the 2010 <a href="census">census</a>, there were 6,918 people. In the 2000 census there were 7,650 people, 3,235 households and 1,937 families residing in the city. The <a href="population%20density">population density</a> was 3,768.2 per square mile (1,455.0/km2). There were 3,376 housing units at an average density of 1,662.9 per square mile (642.1/km2). The racial makeup of the city was 95.87% <a href="White%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">White</a>, 0.39% <a href="African%20American%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Black</a> or <a href="Race%20%28United%20States%20Census%29">African American</a>, 1.20% <a href="Native%20American%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Native American</a>, 0.35% <a href="Asian%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Asian</a>, 0.03% <a href="Pacific%20Islander%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Pacific Islander</a>, 0.45% from <a href="Race%20%28United%20States%20Census%29">other races</a>, and 1.70% from two or more races. 0.90% of the population were <a href="Hispanic%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Hispanic</a> or <a href="Latino%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">Latino</a> of any race.
There were 3,235 households, of which 31.6% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 43.6% were <a href="Marriage">married couples</a> living together, 12.1% had a female householder with no husband present, and 40.1% were non-families. 31.4% of all households were made up of individuals, and 12.6% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.35 and the average family size was 2.97.
Age distribution was 25.6% under the age of 18, 8.3% from 18 to 24, 31.8% from 25 to 44, 20.3% from 45 to 64, and 14.0% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 35 years. For every 100 females, there were 91.6 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 86.2 males.
Government.
St. Albans is governed via a mayor, a city manager and city council. The city council consists of six members, each elected from an individual ward. The mayor is elected by citywide vote.
Economy.
Personal income.
In the 2010 census, the <a href="median%20household%20income">median household income</a> was $37,221, and the median family income was $44,286. Males had a median income of $31,340 versus $23,262 for females. The city's <a href="per%20capita%20income">per capita income</a> was $17,853. About 8.5% of families and 9.6% of the population were below the <a href="poverty%20line">poverty line</a>, including 9.2% of those under age 18 and 11.9% of those age 65 or over.
Industry.
The town's <a href="comprehensive%20annual%20financial%20report">comprehensive annual financial report</a> for the fiscal year that ended June 30, 2020, lists the principal employers in the town as <a href="U.S.%20Department%20of%20Homeland%20Security">U.S. Department of Homeland Security</a>'s <a href="U.S.%20Citizenship%20and%20Immigration%20Services">U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services</a> (USCIS) (650 employees), <a href="Northwestern%20Medical%20Center">Northwestern Medical Center</a> (612 employees), Maple Run Unified School District (608 employees), Mylan Technologies Inc. (425 employees), <a href="Dairy%20Farmers%20of%20America">Dairy Farmers of America</a> (95 employees), Sticks & Stuff (92 employees), the City of St. Albans (91 employees), A.N. Deringer, Inc. (80 employees), Peoples Trust Company (47 employees), and SB Collins (40 employees).
The <a href="U.S.%20Citizenship%20and%20Immigration%20Services">USCIS</a> has a service center in St. Albans; the majority of the 1,100 USCIS employees in Vermont are based in St. Albans, and the federal agency is the city's largest employer. The Dairy Farmers of America, a major dairy <a href="Agricultural%20cooperative">cooperative</a>, has a manufacturing plant in St. Albans that produces cream, condensed skim milk, and <a href="milk%20powder">milk powder</a>. The chocolate and cocoa supplier <a href="Barry%20Callebaut">Barry Callebaut</a> has a facility in the city.
Infrastructure.
Health care.
The <a href="Northwestern%20Medical%20Center">Northwestern Medical Center</a> is a hospital serving the city and the Franklin County area.
Railways.
Saint Albans is the northern terminus of the <a href="Vermonter%20%28train%29">Vermonter</a>, an all-coach train operated by <a href="Amtrak">Amtrak</a>, the national passenger rail system. The train operates daily between Saint Albans and <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a>
The train formerly continued from Saint Albans to <a href="Montreal">Montreal</a> and was named the <a href="Montrealer%20%28train%29">Montrealer</a>, but that connection was discontinued.
Education.
St. Albans is home to St. Albans City School, an elementary school for students in kindergarten through eighth grade, and <a href="Bellows%20Free%20Academy%2C%20St.%20Albans">Bellows Free Academy, St. Albans</a>, a public high school serving students from many towns in the southern half of Franklin Country.
